The book is written to give a general audience a bit of an idea on how consciousness and our brain works.

This books attempts to explain how the human brain works. I say attempt because the author himself admits we do not yet completely know how the brain functions. This book covers topics like pseudo-pregnancy, phantom limbs, hemi-neglect and so on.Pseudo-pregnancy is a state where a woman believes she is pregnant and shows all physical signs including a protruding belly, but who is not really pregnant. The woman even gives birth and loses her fat belly, but there is no baby. The author tries to explain why the body and brain fail to see the truth about the baby’s absence. And how the belly grows fat even though there is no baby.When a patient loses a limb to amputation, he might continue to feel its existence and might even feel pain in the absent limb. The author refers to this as the phantom limb and tries to cure such patients with innovative methods. He even performs amputation over a phantom limb, which he himself finds amusing.There are many such scenarios/conditions listed in the book and each one of them is as interesting and thought provoking. Through these “stories” and the author’s explanation, we get a glimpse of how our brain might be functioning. One bitter truth that is revealed to us is that we hardly know how it functions!Dr. Ramachandran keeps his language simple and layman-friendly. There are medical jargons, but he gives enough explanation for us non-medical readers to understand and appreciate. I wish I had paid more attention in my biology classes. Some chapters are hard to understand and you need to read this in chunks.This is not your typical bedtime reading. It is heavy reading and requires your brain to be functional when you read. A must read for those who find the medical world and human brain even slightly intriguing.

In the beginning, Ramachandran mentions that he isn't used to the idea of writing pop-science books & that he preferred he didn't write one. The strange thing is that as you go along, you'll come across moments when you feel so as well.But please make no mistake, this book is not to be missed.First of all, Ramachandran is very versatile & his flow is extremely comforting. He might be talking about neurology in one sentence, & then evolution in the next, & philosophy by the end of the page.Ironically, his merit is his demerit. You see, this is a neurologist, which means that when he speaks of neurology, you'll sense greatness in the words. Quite often did he sent me on a trance speaking of the mysteries & conundrums of the brain. But when he begins speaking about philosophy, things get tangled up. Of course you can't study neurology without philosophy. And of course the Freudian views in there must have been included & there was no other way to complete the brilliance of this book without them. But to dedicate a whole chapter for them (the final chapter) wasn't the move to be made, in my opinion. Ramachandran is an awesome neurologist, but he just should drop the philosophy.On the other hand, he's quite the genius in evolutionary theories as well. The parts he speaks of evolution & laughter are some of the best in the book. It's obvious how highly he thinks of people like Darwin & Dawkins. And it's quite remarkable how his approach towards evolution included no insults towards creationism as he didn't indulge in them so much. He just took the part he needed of the topic, which I hoped he would do with philosophy as well.All in all, this book delivers some intriguing neurology mysteries & is quite a fun ride to take.

Ramachandran continues to delight with his witty style. Neuroscience as a field is indeed exciting and I could not put the book down. However having read his Tell Tale Brain, I had much less surprises from this one. I think his arguments were more sophisticated in the other book. I adore balance in any argument and I get that in plenty from Vilayanur. I was particularly delighted about a section where he explains the difference between "experience" and "scientific explanations". This is what he calls qualia. "They are aspects of my brain that seem to make the scientific description incomplete - from my point of view." He explains this using the example of color. How would you explain the color "red" to a color blind scientist? The scientist might be able to distinguish red from green using laws of wavelength, and yet he would never be able to come close to your experience of the color "red". In fact, he uses this example to explain how people experience God. Having said that, this explanation did make me a little uncomfortable. He suggests that there are neurons that get excited during religious experiences. From this theory of qualia and from his experimental evidence of excited neurons, it is possible to state that a non-believer may never completely understand the experience. Having said that, I was uncomfortable that belief/faith was explained only from an individual point of view. In his later book, Vilayanur does speak of mirror neurons and that many of our behaviors are learned from social environment that we are a part of. Neuroscience is indeed exciting and Vilayanur writes well. I rate Tell Tale Brain higher, though :)

This is pretty much the benchmark by which all pop-science books should be judged. I can only judge it from the perspective of someone who very much isn't a practising neurosurgeon, not even in my spare time. Nope, brains are very much a grey mass best kept within the skull, that's about the limits of my knowledge. So if there's grievous factual errors in here, or huge sweeping jumps in logic, they've passed me by.However, what we do have is a number of example-driven chapters, explaining the tenuous link between the brain and its host body, eventually culminating in a debate about what constitutes the concept of self. The prose is engaging, the author's personality comes across with huge warmth and wit, and the concepts are explained in a manner which could not be clearer, there is no need to have any previous understanding of neurological concepts here. In fact, its not just the clarity and simplicity of the prose that's surprising, the treatments, experiments and conclusions all share the same attributes. The fact that one of VS Ramachandran's breakthroughs came about by getting patients to wear a cardboard box with a mirror in it, to treat the pain of phantom limbs, says everything about the author's style. Rarely going down the road of convoluted theory, he takes what he knows about something, and applies simple logic and practical solutions to his patients. Then applies the same simple, concise approach to describing the rationale.Fascinating, engaging, remarkably clear, and containing a wealth of information about how the brain works with body-image, limbs, senses and psyche. A triumph.

I've read a lot of Oliver Sacks before so I wanted to try one of his contemporaries. Ramaschandran reads a lot like Sacks but perhaps without as much of the "phenomenological" personal element of his case studies; the empathy laden descriptions that Sacks evoke that make you feel part of the patients world. VS instead delves a lot more into the theory, although more often than not this takes the form of wild speculations about untouched ground in neuroscience (that while enjoyable for their own merits, are not backed by the research). The book starts with a thorough exploration of the phantom limb phenomenon, one that VS explores deftly and deeply. Before it begins to get tiresome, he branches off into other interesting phenomenon such as visual neglect, Capgras, nosagnosia and other curious maladies. Unfortunately some of these later topics are not treated with as much detail and depth as the exploration of phantom limbs. The book concludes with a rather tangentially discussion on phantom pregnancies and a collection of other miscellaneous disorders as well as ruminations on the constituents and nature of consciousness, which I felt were beyond the original scope of the book -- it did not feel like what I had signed up for! I feel as though VS has some very entertaining (albeit speculative) ideas, but perhaps has too large a scope to integrate all of his interesting ideas seamlessly.

This is one of the best popular science books I've read in the last decade. A potential Nobel winner, Ramachandran -- a renowned neuroscientist at the University of California San Diego -- describes his intriguing analyses, and deductions of the structure of the human brain, with great wit and eloquence. The neurological challenges that he discusses span a wide gamut: from phantom limbs (where people continue to 'feel' amputated limbs) to Capgras' syndrome (where a person sees his mother and is reminded of his mother rather than recognizing her as such); from blindsight (where a person cannot 'see' an object, and yet exhibits motor responses to its presence), to heightened religious feelings accompanying seizures. Ramachandran surmises aspects of the brain's architecture from the symptomology of these disorders, and designs and conducts simple clinical experiments seeking confirmation for his hypotheses. There is something stirring about attacking fundamental questions through low-tech experiments -- something reminiscent of the experiments of Galileo, and the thought experiments of Einstein. Finally, I admire the open-mindedness, intellectual honesty, and scientific spirit he brings to problematic topics such as the neural basis of consciousness, and religious experience. It takes great sophistication and wisdom -- something that is demonstrated in ample measure in this book -- to address these areas without sounding specious, oversimplifying, or vague.

Here, Ramachandran writes on neuroscience, psychology, delusions of death, delusions of family, and everything in between. His witty approaches are often elegant, tackling big and small questions of neuroscience with skepticism and excitement alike. Phantoms does not shy from supporting with evidence and historical scientific context; thus, it remains challenging and thoughtful while still being approachable. I’m partial to Oliver Sacks and the empathy he carefully writes with, but I can also appreciate the openings here in each chapter. Ramachandran and Sacks both incorporate their thoughts on other disciplines – and how literature, philosophy, and art may better answer some of our biggest problems than our science currently can.When I met Ramachandran last fall, I asked how best scientists should write on their research for the mass consumption. He said that the keys to good writing are excitement and empathy alike. Why do you care about what you’re doing, and how do you bring that into focus? And how do you relate that to others? Phantoms, I believe, rings true for both principles: it is difficult to deny the compelling brilliance and charisma that shines through this work. Metaphors abound, Phantoms even at times reads similarly to Holmes as we investigate these illuminations of the mind.A must-read.

we all have a 'body image' (perhaps genetic) that is totally in our minds, its boundaries are not the boundaries of our skin, or where our nose is in space and time. and what's crazy is, it takes only several seconds to alter this body image. try this (i'm going to try it tonight, using chris and justine). sit on a chair blindfolded. have somebody else sit on a chair right in front of you, facing the same direction you're sitting, as if you are sitting on pullman busses. then ask the third friend to take your right hand, and with your finger, stroke the nose of the person sitting in front of you, while the third person with her free hand strokes your nose at the same rhythm she is stroking your finger on your friend's nose... in about 10 seconds magic happens... your finger is touching your friend's nose... your third friend's finger is on your nose... even though the nose you are touching is not your own nose, because you nose is also being touched at the same time, it feels as if you are touching your own nose! but your arm is extended out... so, it feels like your nose is extended out two feet... thus, your body image, of which we think we are very sure because we've lived with it a whole lifetime, changes in 10 seconds..

This book, written by neurologist V. S. Ramachandran, suggests that by looking at case studies of individuals with particular types of brain injuries we can learn a lot about the the human mind. He looks at examples of patients with phantom limb syndrome, vision problems, paralysis and other problems and uses his understanding of their neurological (physiological) causes to speculate on their implications about the structure and functioning of a "normal" human brain.I found this very interesting to read, with descriptions of both symptoms and anatomy being very clear and easy to follow, although it is a little repetitive in places. However, although I know very little about neurology myself, I found some of his theories hard to swallow - it was often unclear if he was neglecting to mention the evidence he had to back them or if there was no evidence at all. I am particularly skeptical of his explanations for foot-fetishes and anorexia.A quote which I think sums up Ramachandran's view of the brain well: "Freud's most valuable contribution was his discovery that your conscious mind is simply a facade and that you are completely unaware of 90 percent of what really goes on in your brain."

All in all, a pretty decent book. It's got some great insights into how the brain likely works, using cases as examples, like patients with phantom limbs, blindsight, Capgras syndrome, anosognosia, and many other fascinating neurologic disorders.From a scientific perspective, I view Dr. Ramachandran as quite interesting from a theoretical standpoint - he likes to dive into philosophy and conjecture more than other scientists. This is both a blessing and a curse. As a blessing, it makes his work much more readable, much more expansive, and brimming with potential. As a curse, it makes his work stand on shakier legs.He readily attests to formulating ideas based on one or two perfect cases, rather than looking at large group of many patients. In science, this can unfortunately lead to erroneous conclusions, and I remember feeling that he strayed a little far our in his conjectures a couple times in this book. However, if the conjectures based on these perfect cases are correct, it can also lead to solid theories that later are backed up by better studies. I believe that is what he hopes for.So I guess that means I'd say the book is interesting, good for scientific theory on how the mind works, and a worthwhile read. That said, not all ideas in it should be taken as law.

You've got to read this one if working of the 'mind' bewilders you. Ramachandhan takes you through the case studies of the patients and makes you meet them. You are compelled to think about them and the way they talked about their 'phnatom limb'. It seems like a heavy read with the name 'neuroscience' associated to it. Ramachandran

PS.-In chapter 11 he mentions about how Multiple Personality Disordered patients are ignored and not widely studied, even the brief assumption & explanation (like how one of the personality can be diabetic or posses different eye colour and the other personality maybe near or far sighted all in one body) imparting his opinion seemed so interesting I really hope he embarks & finds a breakthrough leading Phantom in the brains pt.2 sequel

So this book is basically a collection of neurology cases presented as chapter introductions. The case is explained, and used as an example of a larger theme or concept in neurology. The book covers phantom limbs, pseudocyesis and other physical mysteries connected to neurological phenomena, interesting cortical strokes, temporal lobe epilepsy and piety, and a lot of other things that I'm forgetting right now.There's an interesting mix of brain science and philosophy, and stories about things that most people will have a hard time even believing are true. The stories are all amazing and written in a way that is accessible to people that may not have experience with medical terminology.If you are interested in neuroscience at all, read this book. It is a good thing to read after having looked at The Man Who Mistook His Wife For A Hat by Oliver Sacks. The two are very similar, but Phantoms delves a little bit deeper into the atual neural pathways involved in these brain anomalies.

A book of reviews of patients with different brain-related diseases, a method that - the author claims - help us gain insight into the workings of the human brain. And to me he seems right. In his own admission, much of what he suggests is speculative, but there's enough science in there too.I've read about people not seeing with their left eye, but still perceiving information from the blind area, people losing vision only to have the brain fill in the missing world with, e.g., cartoons, people with a lost arm still feeling their (missing) fingers, people with paralyzed limbs whose brain tricks them into thinking that they can still move the paralyzed limb (and do stuff with it!) and many more.Told like this, it sounds like a collection of stories from a crappy magazine reporting paranormal events, but when you get to understand that the brain is nothing more than a complicated machinery in which stuff can selectively go wrong, you realize it's just our ignorance that prevents us from accepting such weird behaviour as real.

"During the last three decades, neuroscientists throughout the world have probed the nervous system in fascinating detail and have learned a great deal about the laws of mental life and about how these laws emerge from the brain. The pace of progress has been exhilarating, but — at the same time — the findings make many people uncomfortable. It seems somehow disconcerting to be told that your life, all your hopes, triumphs and aspirations simply arise from the activity of neurons in your brain. But far from being humiliating, this idea is ennobling, I think. Science — cosmology, evolution and especially the brain sciences — is telling us that we have no privileged position in the universe and that our sense of having a private nonmaterial soul "watching the world" is really an illusion (...) Once you realize that far from being a spectator, you are in fact part of the eternal ebb and flow of events in the cosmos, this realization is very liberating. Ultimately this idea also allows you to cultivate a certain humility — the essence of all authentic religious experience." (page 256)

Simple experiments and logical conclusion, that's this book. Brain which once seemed fuzzy, with this book comes to me as a hope that mental phenomena too can be made exact just like other sciences.Though titled as "Phantom..", it's much more than that. How mad people can have extraordinary eye to details (which can be seen in their painting), or how exceptionally fast are they at maths (instances of them multiplying 8 digit numbers within seconds.). Why does the sucking on toe, gives erection? How scratching on the face can be a solution to the itch in Phantom limb? HowRamachandran does very simple experiments in attempt to map the brain. He raises some very profound questions that has confirmed my beliefs in metaphysics/religion/God in general and Quran in particular. He asks, when an amputated limb can survive its life (through phantom), why not the entire human being (through its soul)?I would recommend this book to anyone who has at one point or another got curious about how the mind works but never knew where to start with.

I am 'enlightened' after reading this one.Books like these make me wonder,'What took me so long to pick this one up?'Damn,I am lucky to have been alive and read this!There is so much of insight about the human brain in this book that it somewhere has changed my perception on life.I could never imagine or even know about phantom limbs,face recognition,denial syndromes,divine interventions,even the complex procedure of 'seeing' and you would not even think about the complexity involved in 'laughing' and even 'phantom pregnancy'!It is seriously a wonder how a mere protoplasm in the brain can put us in so much awe.It is somewhere hurtful to know the hopes,the desires everything is almost a facade and 'seeing is believing' is not true.The author probes into Freud's defense principles and even Darwin and Wallace's theory on evolution.He aptly quotes Shakespeare,'Our revels are now ended.These our actors,As I foretold you,were all spirits andAre melted into air,into thin air..We are such stuffAs dreams are made on,And out little lifeIs rounded with a sleep'Will re-read!

This was recommended reading from a peer. I'm glad I do not have any close friends or family members with brain diseases or afflictions such as those studied and described in this book. However, what has been conveyed is fascinating: -	Early experiments of how the brain represents knowledge and belief where there are mental and physical disorders of the brain.-	People were considered crazy until neural circuitry in their brains could be understood.-	I was not aware the left brain controls the right arms and lefts. And likewise, the right brain controls the left arms and legs.-	Stroke in the right brain makes people tend to be blissfully indifferent to their predicament. Left brain just doesn’t get that upset.-	Stroke in the left brain makes people more anxious, depressed and worried. Right brain frets about everything.-	Some brain disorders cause people to ‘neglect to see things’, they are not truly blind-	Do not reject an idea simply because you cannot think of a mechanism that explains it!

Have you ever "thought" about how you think? Why do you smile when you hear a joke or feel angry just because somebody has crossed your path?Did you ever wonder why you like the calm peaceful mountain mist? Did the question ever hunted you "What is going inside the brain?" Well, they call some really virtual thing as "Mind" but, do mind really exist? Everything is in the brain itself. This book here, is an eye opener for people like us who had all the questions in their minds forever and was not able to find the proper answer from anywhere. I really liked the fact that Mr. Ramachandran had taken the way of a detective to get deeper and deeper into the mystery of the hugely complicated subject and showed that in front of the reader.If you are really serious about the matter how the most complicated machine in the universe works, you should, well let me correct myself, you MUST, read this book.

The author makes a novice understand the anatomy of the brain, its functioning and the brain linkages to different bodily functions to an extent. He has provided case studies and several real life examples to explain these concepts. Dr. V.S. Ramachandran, had explained clearly about the phantoms in the brain not limiting to the lost limbs alone, but also, unconceived child and unrecognizable parents. This book is an excellent source for all neuroscience enthusiasts, people with special interests like me that wanted to understand about the phantom limb, nonfiction readers. I wholeheartedly agree that, this subject is extremely difficult to comprehend other than someone that has experienced it personally or kith and kin.Without reading this book, I wouldn’t have understood what trauma my mom was going through and in turn explained this to her so that she too got convinced about the root cause of the phantom limb. I had rated this book 4/5 merely because of the personal reasons.

I am really enjoying this book although it's a bit disappointing that so many of Ramachandran's examples are taken from other prominent authors -- if you've read Oliver Sacks or Paul Broks, then you're already familiar with a good number of the anecdotes in this book.But Ramachandran's investigation into different phenomenon of the mind are refreshingly random. It's great to read a sentence that goes like this: "Maybe xyz, though, the chances of that are slim, but wouldn't it be interesting?" Rather than a set of theories of mind that are just as speculative, but presented as fact.He also happens to be laugh-out-loud funny. Case in point: "If I ever locate an MPD patient with just two personalities, I intend to eliminate doubt by sending the person two bills. If he pays both, I'll know he's for real. If he doesn't I'll know he's a fake. In either case, I can't lose."

Every weird human behavior can be traced to a neuroanatomical abnormality, nothing is unexplainable.Engaging enthralling and well-explained for the most part, except for some of the obligatory wtf last chapter on consciousness/ qualia. A lot of cool stuff regarding the nature of perception/ pain drawing from patients with strokes in specific areas, also ingenious experiments by Ramachandran. I have much respect for him but he name-dropped Francis Crick one too many times. Not that it matters, he's made many important contributions to neurology himself and therefore is just as good a scientist, just that he made advances in less visible areas."So here is the greatest irony of all: that the self that almost by definition is entirley private is to a significant extent a social construct - a story you make up for others."

Essentially a collection of very interesting case studies (plus embellishments) that illustrate how, with nothing more than access to a world's worth of highly unusual patients, a wealth of McGuiver-esque ingenuity, and the background knowledge that comes with being one of the world's top neurologists, you can shed light on some of neuroscience's must puzzling conundrums. VS comes across as funny, practical, and likeable, and towards the end he unfurls some lengthier theories that are not far short of fascinating (on how laughter may have arisen, the role of the 'peak-shift effect' in the origin of new species, and - the theory he's always building towards - the location of consciousness in the brain). Damn nearly five stars, but at times it does get ever so slightly samey and repetitive. Only ever so slightly, mind. Four point four.

I'm not sure what I expected from reading this book... Perhaps deep conclusions about how human cognition works, perhaps some pieces of the map to our intellectual coastlines, but what I mostly got was all sorts of neurological patient curiosities with little value for me. Someone more interested in these odd cases of people with brain damage or whatever thinking they can clap when they in fact cannot, might be of more interest to someone else. If someone slapped this book to the back of Oliver Sack's book, Hallucinations, you wouldn't even notice you are reading a different book.I mean no disrespect towards the author, and it's mainly my skepticism and my need for evidence when I say that many conclusions Ramachandran draws seem a bit too baseless, a bit too fantastic. Often times I wasn't sure whether I was reading conjecture or science.

This book is on a subject I'm deeply interested in: psychological disorders. I found it quite interesting. Ramachandran's writing style is pleasing. This is in sharp contrast with perhaps the best known writer in this field, Oliver Sacks. This book was accessible, lacking the pomposity of Sacks's work.The book is a bit uneven. I enjoyed the earlier parts much more than later parts. The author warns in the preface that some of the book's contents are empirical, verifiable explanations and some are quite philosophical, abstract, or speculative. It was the grounded chapters that I gained the most pleasure from. I did appreciate Ramachandran's defense of Freud's theory of defense mechanisms. All in all, this is quite a book, with a range of interesting topics investigated with experimentation, conjecture, and speculation.

This took me MONTHS to finish; it was fascinating reading, but I wanted to read it well and it could get technical, especially when flipping back and forth to the footnotes. Ramachandran is a neuroscientist famous for his work on phantom limbs, and he takes pride in his research in anomalous phenomena in neuroscience. The first several chapters focus on phantom limbs - their causes, their effects, and the unconventional approach to "curing" them and thinking about the brain in general that Ramachandran successfully explored. The end of the book diverges and discusses other phenomena related to the same mechanisms, which was just as interesting (though harder to get through, since it wasn't as directly connected). He writes well on some complex topics, illuminating them enough for enterprising non-neuroscientists to understand.

An amazing book, fascinating in revealing what we have learned about brain function through the study of patients with damage to specific brain areas, other neurological disorders, and years of neurological research. Amusing, detailed, and accessible, the book is everything fans of The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat and Other Clinical Tales will enjoy, including a somewhat tongue in cheek suggestion of The Man Who Mistook His Foot for a Penis as an alternate title for Phantoms in the Brain: Probing the Mysteries of the Human Mind.

Read this book if you have even a passing interest in neurology. His experiments are innovative and his explanations are clear and lucid. You realize that it is possible to learn so much about the workings of the brain without fancy technology or invasive surgery. Ramachandran's ideas and general dismissal of philosophers or the whole field of philosophy might disturb you (or entertain you if you are not a philosophy major).The entire last chapter on consciousness and qualia was frankly mind-numbing. It seemed completely out-of-place in an otherwise brilliant and well-thought-out book.His self-aggrandizement can be a little annoying at times. I lost count of the number of times he claimed that he was the first to do/achieve something. Overall, a great read if you can tolerate some self aggrandizement and ramblings about philosophy.

I found this much more interesting than Oliver Sacks' book. They deal with a lot of the same cases, but Ramachandran has an approach I really liked, where he clearly differentiates between conjecture and proven theories, but doesn't discount at all the validity of having multiple, completely hypothetical scenarios, in order to arrive at a conclusion, even if a lot of the potential answers are entirely wrong.Great, fun, and approachable writing. I love how he isn't afraid to deal with extremely controversial topics such as consciousness, and feels free to give us potential solutions to perhaps unsolvable problems, he's always taking a very scientific approach and trying to find the flaws in his own methods.For beginner neuroscience, this is the most approachable and informative book I've found so far. Super recommended.

I read this in college as part of a cognitive neuroscience course. It has been a few years, so the material is not fresh in my mind, but I do remember my classmates having a positive response to this book. It was informative and well represented what was, at the time of publication, the most up-to-date research on the various brain maladies discussed. That research was presented in an accessible manner, such that I think even your average reader would be able to follow and understand the material. In addition, the writing was engaging, so this book would likely appeal to readers who might not normally enjoy non-fiction. It wasn’t written in the dry manner that is often characteristic of academic writing. “Phantoms in the Brain” represents an example of great science writing, and I would absolutely read more from this author.

This is a wonderful book for people who are not scientists, but enjoy reading about the absolutely mind-boggling things that our brains do. It is satisfying in the same way that reading a glossy gossip magazine is, but for people who are interested in neurological disorders more than celebrity fashion. I mean all this in the best way possible. Ramachandran goes off on unorthodox "what-if" tangents that probably wouldn't go over well in strict scientific writing but make a very exciting read for the casually curious. The case studies he presents are so astounding, they read like fantasy, and unlike most dry medical writing, the author seems to encourage the reader to make his or her own guesses at what is really going on. I like that. This book is a good good time.

This book is about the disparities between reality and what people's conscious perceptions sometimes tell them. It presents a lot of evidence towards its conclusions in an easy to digest way. Lots of interesting case reports, a little bit of science, a smattering of deep and famous philosophical quotes.While I was reading it, I found myself breaking conversational silences by summarizing parts of it that I thought were interesting or surprising (to the kinds of friends who I thought might be interested). I took that as a good sign about its content.Ramachandran is no Oliver Sachs when it comes to stylish and compassion-inspiring writing; I dealt with the pompous/condescending/self-congratulatory tone by laughing at it.

I think it's a good book, but not great. I found the writing a little stiff and the humor often seemed pasted in - sometimes I half expected to see little smilies :^) next to the funny parts. But enough being critical. The meat of this book is the author's thinking on how the human brain works, through his consideration of a wide variety of neurological disorders like phantom limbs, vision problems, and various aphasias and agnosias. That stuff is really fascinating, and some of the author's conclusions are unexpected and insightful. He tries to tie it all together at the end by summarizing what it all might mean for the concept of self. Guess what? You are not who you think you are. I'll recommend this for anyone with an interest in the brain and the mind.

This starts off as an extremely good book about the author's direct experience and experiments dealing with the phenomenon of phantom limbs. It discusses the current knowledge of how certain parts of the brain works, and it relates some simple experiments that demonstrate how the brain-body connection is much stranger than we assume it to be.But sadly the book trudges steadily down hill from that beginning. The book starts with the doctor's strongest specialty. Then it delves into cases he has less experience with, then well documented cases he's only read about, then questionable cases. Finally it descends into areas of pure speculation. While no doubt some people will find the speculation cool, I'd rather he had stuck to the science.

Brilliant book. I regularly recommend it to my medical students. It rekindles an interest in neurology that many students find daunting in its complexity and variety. Slightly technical for the non-medic, but well worth the effort. This leads one to a philosophical inquiry as well. I wish Ramachandran (and Blakesley) would update this book with information from the functional MRI studies that are pouring in now. Some of the extensive notes are irritating in the sense that they are at the back of the book. I understand the purpose of putting it at the end, but I would have preferred the notes in the bottom of the relevant page. Other than that particular irritant, loved this book. On par or better than Sacks' books.

Very engaging read on the workings of the brain and human behaviors. Okay, it was at times a tad dry. Mind-body interactions (including phantom limb syndrome, false pregnacy, spontaneous and uncontrollable laughter, and how the blind see the world) are discussed through some crazy case studies. My personal favorite revelation: evidence from brain damaged stroke patients shows that a spontaneous, genuine smile is coordinated by one specific area of the brain while a smile produced for the camera or on demand takes place in an entirely different location and requires more connections of energy. No wonder I always feel annoyed when someone tells me to smile while I'm going about my business!

An excellent book providing insights into the working of human brain. The author uses an unique approach of understanding how normal brain works based on his observations of abnormal brains.Dr V.Ramachandran also touches upon aspects like what is beauty?, why we laugh? etc. His general rules about what makes objects more pleasing to brain with examples form ancient Indian temple sculptures (Chola bronze sculptures) is wonderful. I rate this book highly because of its ability to satiate large audience (from a lay man who is only interested in understanding functions of brain grossly to an informed reader who has a scientific bent of mind).Kudos to Dr. Ramachandran!

This book has been on my "to-read" shelf for a very long time. I am lucky to have friends who buy me books from my wishlist. :)And what a book it is! This is the first time that I am reading anything in neuroscience and the brain is definitely a whole Universe unto itself. Dr. Ramachandran (called the "Marco Polo of Neuroscience" by Richard Dawkins) makes the brain accessible to laypeople like me with great success, flair and panache. After reading this book, all senses of self, what we are, who we really identify ourselves to be- all those lines become very, very blurry. This book whets your appetite for answers and makes you wonder what it really means to be human and to be conscious. A delightful read and highly recommended to everyone.

This was my first real introduction into the subject of the study of mind, and it made me fall in love with it.The author clearly delimits facts revealed by experiments, and his personal speculations. And in all fairness, V.S. Ramachandran's speculations are very reasonable, as far as a lay-person as myself can tell.I am not going to bother reiterating the things discussed in the book, the author can do a much better job than I can. But suffice it to say, that the human brain is much more quirky in its behavior than one might intuit, and it's the shattering of this intuition that is the most worthwhile thing one can expect from this book.

Phantom Limbs, Hallucinations, mental denial, sensory disruption, absolutely fascinating.V.S. Ramachandran peers into the part(s) of the mind that we do not ordinarily notice and discusses such topics as body image, vision, consciousness, and sensory perception. He writes with large words, yet with an air of humor and light-heartedness. Something that is refreshing in a science theory book.Very highly recommended to anyone who is interested in such things. I must admit, however, that I was a little disappointed with the final chapter. I found it kind of boring, redundant, and anti-climactic.

The experiments Ramachandran designed to investigate the phantom limb phenomenon (experienced by some people following an amputation) are ingenious and elegant and can fairly be said to have advanced our understanding of how proprioception (our awareness of our body in space) is organised in the human brain. Further experiments on the blind spot are also interesting, but Ramachandran allows himself to be led into speculation about what all this might mean for a theory of mind (mainly to expand the material to a publishable length). I can speculate too - I prefer hard facts in a book of this kind.

Mind-blowing! The book covers anatomical to functional aspects of the brain. The book scientifically reveals how and why brain is the crux of the notion called 'self' and how perceptions can change with a slight tweak in the connections between the neurons. The case studies only add on to the wonder of simplicity within the complexity. As Dr Francis Crick said for the book, "If you are at all interested in how your brain works, this is the book you must read."[P.S. After reading this, most of you will come to accept the fact that heart is nothing more than an organ that purifies and pump blood in the body. It's the brain that thinks as well as "FEELS" for you.]

Everyone compares this book and author to Oliver Sacks and his works, but it really does not compare. Sacks is simply AMAZING while Mr. Ramaetc. is just interesting. I think this book got onto my to-read list because it's listed as one of Sack's books on Goodreads, though he just wrote the foreword. Sacks is complimentary in the forward because this book is clearly no competition! It is basically a repetition of almost all of Sacks' interesting stories with additional dry, very technical science-y explanations. I happen to like the science-y explanations about 60% of the time while I was reading, so this book gets 3 stars. Only read this if you've run out of Sacks' books!

This book is a consideration of brain and cognitive functions through a review of patient cases, most from the author but a few others as well. Ramachandran uses these cases to elucidate the function of healthy brains and ultimately to consider consciousness and the sense of self. He also considers some of the psychological, philosophical, and religious perspectives, coming back to science with appropriate tests of these ideas. This book has lots of good information and summarizes cognitive science. His presentation is quite readable with many illustrations. His speculations are quite reasonable and interesting. Highly recommended.

Amazing book on how the brain works.Brings up many unique conditions that have plagued the human race but instead of just analyzing them, the author leverages these cases to learn more about the brains functions. The cases mentioned are fascinating and each one reveals something more and deeper about the science of how our brain works. Wasn't very impressed with the ending segment on qualia. Seemed rather speculative and the idea gave me a feeling of being half-developed. That's the only reason I give this book 4 stars. Aside from that it's a great read for anyone interested in how humans work.

i've always been strangely fascinated by neuroscience in general, and this book does a pretty good job of balancing curious facts and anecdotes and with hard science. maybe there's a little too much hard science (or maybe i'm not that smart!) but i've read this twice now and there are still some portions that are too technical for me to easily wrap my own head around... still, as a sort of "primer" regarding the inner-workings of the brain (and the broader subject of human consciousness), i've not yet encountered a better book.

Ramachandran (and Blakeslee) evoke the same style of drawing from case studies to illustrate problems and possibilities of neuroscience diagnoses and treatments as does Oliver Sacks (who wrote the Forward of this book). The best part is that they do not come off as technological determinists, rather, they broadly define cases and describe historical approaches to the same and similar problems. They outline what is not known and what is known, and how this information has been and is being used in popular culture and in professional neuroscientific circles. Great for broad audiences.

This book is more educational than literary, but I found it fascinating! The studies of Dr. Ramachandran make for great reading, as they are not overly scientific. They take more real world applications of the cognitions and functions of both the typical and damaged brain. What you will learn is about all the fascinating tricks our brain can play on us. A must read if you find neuroscience/neurology at all interesting. I think they made a 60 minutes type bio about him and his work years ago. Good stuff!

Holy Freak! This is such an incredible book! It is a fascinating look into how the mind and the physical brain work together. The author is a brain specialist as well as clinical psychologist and has figured out ingenious ways to physically treat ailments society has long labeled as psychological issues like phantom limbs and hallucinations. The language is "dumb" enough for anyone to read and enjoy yet it is also scientific enough for students of medicine and/or psychology to understand the methods and appreciate the author's credentials. Super read.

Really interesting work about the physical roots of various aspects of mind, like self awareness, religious/spiritual sensations, perception of one's body, etc. He does an excellent job of refuting the notion that studying the physical side of this stuff somehow robs it of significance or "reality". He points out, for example, that we can locate religious sensations to a particular part of the brain. We can do the same for colour perception, and just because some folks do perceive colour and others don't doesn't mean there is no colour....:>)

Wow, I thought I knew a thing or two about cognitive thought processes, and the interconnectedness of mind-body-spirit, but this book made me re-think everything about being a conscious human being. I bought it in 1998, when my son was recovering from a brain injury, and while it is somewhat clinical, it is at the same time fascinating! When my adult children ask me questions about God, I cannot leave out recommending this book to read, as it offers insight into how we as people percieve reality.

I loved this book. Ramachandran is a genius. He's taken huge intuitive leaps toward explicating some of the more bizarre neurological phenomena on the books, like phantom limbs, synaesthesia, dysmorphic disorder, etc. The book is a great blend of science and storytelling: the narrative is funny and engaging, and the subject matter is fascinating. It's amazing to think that the frontier in neuroscience is still wide enough for somebody to take a maverick, sort of Sherlock Holmes approach toward cutting-edge research.

Phantoms in the Brain is a wonderful collection of case studies, each of which testifies to the astonishing, albeit often terrible, ways in which an individual's perceptions can change on account of brain malfunctions. Ramachandran's writing style is clear and concise, as well as humorous, though he does tend to hypothesize a little too wildly at times for my taste. His research, however, is well-cited and fascinating and I recommend Phantoms in the Brain as a good pop-science intro (but only an intro) to neuroscience.

"Phantoms in the brain” is an amazing book! The work and structure of our brain is one of the biggest mysteries. An understanding about human brain changes thanks to the latest technologies and the progress in neuroscience. But we are still far from answers. Ramachandran is definitely a brilliant scientist and writer who can talk about the most unique experiments and ask the most complex questions in an easy to understand way. Today we can unlock some nature's secrets, but the existence of mind is still an enigma.

Mostly entertaining, something of an updated version of Oliver Sacks classic "Man who mistook his wife for a hat", but really goes off the rails in the final couple of chapters, where I think he lets his desire for his religious/cultural beliefs to blind him. Anyone who can state that there is more to Deeprak Chopra and Andrew Weil than New Age psychobabble and that they have something real and important to say, while at the same time acknowledging that there is no evidence to back up any of it, has abandoned skepticism.

Popular science book on neurology. The book explores how the brain is involved in our perception of body and health. Many examples illustrate the connection, e.g., amputations, strokes, trauma. Book also mentions Stephen Pinker and Andrew Weil, who recognize the limits of normal atomistic approach to understanding health. Last chapter dealt with problems understanding consciousness. Book's scientific approach is interesting because many of the neurological problems would have been considered psychosis very recently.

This is a well-written and occasionally humorous book that deals with many important ideas in contemporary neuroscience.It deals with some interesting issues, such as phantom limb pain, Capgras syndrome (in which someone in convinced that a close friend or relative is an imposter impersonating them), the related Cotard's syndrome (in which someone believes that they are dead), and religious hallucinations related to temporal lobe seizures.Written for a popular audience, it's a simply written but worthwhile book.

This was the first Neuroscience/Psychology book I read. And it was a great experience. The narration technique used by author is story like, which made the stuff sound really interesting. There is certainly lots of information packed in experiences and analysis by the author. There is a point when it becomes way too philosophical, but I guess that is a danger with any research scientist writing a book :-) In all, its a good package. This book opened the world of neuroscience/psychology genre for me. I will say its a must read of its kind.

An excellent book. It has the right proportion of technical details, experimentation, analysis and future work. A perfectly proportioned technical novel. It explains a lot of situations, beliefs, cravings, etc we experience from day to day. It also gives a good insight into how research can proceed and how theories can get better with experiments and results. The writer also raises few philosophical questions that can be argued upon at dinners. Overall it's a wonderful reading experience who is curious about psychology or brain.

A very fascinating book written by neurologist Dr V S Ramachandran where he explores some of the very rare brain disorders like phantom limbs, capgras delusion, paralysis denial, pseudocyesis(false pregnancy) and so on. The book is full of interesting studies that the author and others in the medical and scientific community have conducted. He also explores the different forms of 'self' that are expressed by humans from scientific point of view. All in all it is an interesting book, most certainly readable by someone who is a layman in field of medicine.

Phantoms in the Brain is undoubtedly one of the most fascinating books I have learned. When I read non-fiction, I do so with the objective of learning something new and remarkable. This books does both of that. It has helped me understand the workings of the brain. Not only is the language so much readable but the anecdotal writing drives home the message more often than not. I will not look back at this book as one on neuroscience but one which answers some fundamental questions about human behaviour.

The most interesting book about brain that I read this year spanning many mind-boggling stories of Dr Ramachandran's patients (there's such thing as phantom pregnancy, what??) that he communicated to us with excellent story telling, that even a beginner in neuroscience field would grasp the knowledge.“It seems somehow disconcerting to be told that your life, all your hopes, triumphs and aspirations simply arise from the activity of neurons in your brain. But far from being humiliating, this idea is ennobling, I think."

Fascinating read on a fun collection of a few neurological conditions and what we can learn from them. I was disappointed that even a shred of validity was given to evolutionary psychology and little was mentioned about the issues in the field, not to mention the false assumption that women are monogamous for biological reasons (this is easily debunked when you consider the fact women are more likely to cheat when in monogamous relationships). Also no mention of the shortfalls of research dependent on neuroimaging, which really should have been included.

I had forgotten that I had read this book a while ago. It is a fascinating journey of a doctor who wants to find out why people who miss limbs still feel that they are there. Using a series of experiments and some fascinating case studies, he takes us into the realm of experimental neurology, where we get to learn a lot about ourselves and how our brains work. Although in the same vein as Oliver Sachs books, this one goes more deeply into the workings of the brain, making it a bit less readable, but a bit more fascinating for those with a bent for something more than just 'popular science'

One of my favorites, I've read it several. Describes and gives case histories of some of the most interesting, strange, and thought-provoking neurological disorders. Imagine your parents look like your real parents, but you really think they are impostors. You have a phantom hand that is clenched and painful and by looking at your real hand in a mirror you can unclench the phantom. Good stuff.

This book is AMAZING. Every time I read it it makes me want to go specialize in brain science, and work with the man who wrote the book. It's absolutely fascinating. He investigates all kinds of strange brain disorders to find more out about how our brain works. There are stories of people with phantom limbs, and people who are blind but can still somehow see, people who, after tragic accidents, now believe their own flesh and blood to be impostors. Thrilling book!
